Title.evidence: Randomised Controlled Trial on the Impact of Preoperative Educational Classes on Patient Expectations in THA and TKA

Trial_Design.evidence: Two randomised controlled trials were conducted, one for THA (177 patients) and one for TKA (143 patients).

Participants.evidence: Participants were consecutively enrolled and randomly assigned to either the intervention or control group.

Intervention.evidence: The intervention group received a standard preoperative class plus a joint-specific module addressing recovery during the first 12 months. The control group received only the standard class.

Objective.evidence: This study aimed to determine if preoperative educational classes could modify patients' expectations of their 12-month postoperative recovery following total hip arthroplasty (THA) and total knee arthroplasty (TKA).

Method_Outcome.evidence: The primary outcome was the change in expectation scores, measured preoperatively before and after the class using validated hip-specific or knee-specific surveys.

Randomisation_Allocation.evidence: Randomisation was performed using a computer-generated sequence, and allocation was concealed.

Number_Randomised.evidence: Two randomised controlled trials were conducted, one for THA (177 patients) and one for TKA (143 patients).

Result_Outcome.evidence: In the THA trial, mean changes in expectation scores were +3.3 ± 8 for the intervention group and +4.9 ± 8 for the control group. In the TKA trial, mean changes were −3.4 ± 10 for the intervention group and +2.4 ± 10 for the control group.
